But the real battle was wider, and much deeper. It is no accident that Joseph Frank’s big epigraph for Vol. IV is from Kolakowski’s classic Modernity on Endless Trial, for Dostoevsky’s abandonment of utilitarian socialism for an idiosyncratic moral conservatism can be seen in the same basic light as Kant’s awakening from “dogmatic slumber” into a radical Pietist deontology nearly a century earlier: “By turning against the popular utilitarianism of the Enlightenment, [Kant] also knew exactly that what was at stake was not any particular moral code, but rather a question of the existence or nonexistence of the distinction between good and evil and, consequently, a question of the fate of mankind.”
commentaries: The author quotes Turgenev’s Fathers and Sons to illustrate a radical ideological stance, using it as a literary counterpoint to Dostoevsky’s themes.

The author references Turgenev’s Fathers and Sons as the source of the term 'Nihilists' and as a cultural touchstone for Dostoevsky’s ideological opposition to radical 19th-century Russian youth movements.

raw.title: A Dictionary of Modern American Usage
raw.author: Bryan A. Garner
contexts: Oxford University Press’s recent release of Mr. Bryan A. Garner’s A Dictionary of Modern American Usage

In other words, a rock-ribbed SNOOT is going to be able to find stuff to kvetch about in any usage dictionary, and ADMAU is no exception. But it’s still really, really good. Except for the VOGUE WORDS snafu and the absence of a pronunciation entry on trough,74 the above were pretty much the only quibbles this reviewer could find. ADMAU is thorough and timely and solid, as good as Follett’s and Gilman’s and the handful of other great American usage guides of the century.

But none of this is why Bryan Garner is a genius. ADMAU is a collection of judgments and so is in no way Descriptivist, but Garner structures his judgments very carefully to avoid the elitism and anality of traditional SNOOTitude.

Then it occurred to me that if Objectivity still had a lowercase sense unaffected by modern relativism, maybe Authority did as well. So, just as I’d done w/r/t Garner’s use of judgment, I went to my trusty conservative American Heritage Dictionary and looked up authority. Does any of this make sense? Because this was how I discovered that Bryan Garner is a genius.
Garner’s A Dictionary of Modern American Usage is thus both a collection of information and a piece of Democratic 77 rhetoric.
why Bryan Garner’s ADMAU is so totally sneaky and brilliant and modern.

A Dictionary of Modern American Usage includes a miniessay on vogue words, but it’s a disappointing one in which Garner does little more than list VWs that bug him and say that “vogue words have such a grip on the popular mind that they come to be used in contexts in which they serve little purpose.”
commentaries: The author cites Garner’s dictionary as a significant and comprehensive modern usage guide, highlighting its rhetorical and ideological strengths.
The author praises Garner's dictionary as a superior and balanced work in the field of usage guides, highlighting its thoroughness and its author's rhetorical restraint as key to its authority.

The author argues that Garner's genius lies not in the comprehensiveness of his dictionary but in his rhetorical strategy of neutral, disinterested presentation, which sidesteps the pitfalls of prescriptive elitism.

The author credits Garner with reviving a viable form of linguistic authority by embodying a lowercase, disinterested objectivity that transcends postmodern skepticism, making his dictionary a rhetorical triumph.

The author cites Garner's dictionary as a model of technocratic authority, praising its ethical appeal and its successful redefinition of linguistic authority through reason, experience, and rhetorical persuasion rather than dogmatism.
The author cites Bryan Garner's dictionary as a sophisticated and modern resource that navigates usage debates with strategic insight.
The author critiques Garner's treatment of vogue words in this usage manual, noting that Garner's analysis is superficial and occasionally incorrect.

goodreads_match.title: In the Penal Colony
goodreads_match.description:
"In the Penal Colony" is a short story by Franz Kafka written in German in October 1914, and first published in October 1919.
The story is set in an unnamed penal colony. It describes the last use of an elaborate torture and execution device that carves the sentence of the condemned prisoner on his skin in a script before letting him die, all in the course of twelve hours. As the plot unfolds, the reader learns more and more about the machine, including its origin, and original justification.

raw.author: Ferdinand de Saussure
contexts: This phrase is attributable to Ferdinand de Saussure, the Swiss philologist who more or less invented modern technical linguistics, separating the study of language as an abstract formal system from the historical and comparative emphases of 19th-century philology.
they are doctrinaire positivists who have their intellectual roots in Comte and Saussure and L. Bloomfield

Add the Saussurian/Chomskian consideration that many grammatically ill-formed sentences can also get the propositional content across—“Bear attack Tonto, Tonto heap scared!”—and the number of subliminal options we’re scanning/sorting/interpreting as we communicate with one another goes transfinite very quickly.
commentaries: The author references Saussure as the originator of modern linguistics, noting that descriptivists invoke him but often misinterpret his theories, particularly regarding the arbitrariness of the sign and the langue/parole distinction.
The author cites Saussure as a key intellectual source for Descriptivist linguistics, positioning him as a foundational figure in structural linguistics.
The author cites Saussure’s structuralist linguistics to underscore how meaning operates beyond literal syntax, highlighting the underlying systems of signification that govern communication.

goodreads_match.title: Webster's New International Dictionary, Second Edition
goodreads_match.description: The 1934 Second Edition of Webster's New International Dictionary, often referred to in usage circles as 'Webster's Second', was a monumental American English dictionary. Though published by Merriam-Webster, it was sometimes informally attributed to editors like William Neilson or others involved in its compilation. The citation 'Gilman’s ’89 Webster’s' is a misattribution or colloquial shorthand; no such book by 'Gilman' titled 'Webster’s (1989)' exists. The reference in the text is likely pointing to the 1934 edition, which remained the authoritative version through the 1980s and was frequently cited in usage guides like those mentioned in the context.
